key_mistakes.reason: The move e5 weakens the d5 pawn without developing any pieces, allowing White to seize control of the center.
White missed the opportunity to capture the pawn on e5, which would have given a material advantage.
This move is too passive and misses the opportunity to apply pressure on the e5 pawn.
This move places the knight on an unstable square and allows White to consolidate its position.
Capturing with the knight allows White to strengthen their pawn structure and opens the b-file for the rook.
This blunder loses material by allowing the capture of the d5 pawn with tempo.
White misses an opportunity to put more pressure on the black position by playing Rb1, which could threaten to win the b7 pawn.

recommendations: Focus on developing pieces actively during the opening phase to control the center.
Avoid unnecessary pawn moves that weaken your position without gaining compensating advantages.
Look for tactical opportunities and threats from your opponent to gain material or positional advantages.
Consider the implications of each move on your overall pawn structure and piece coordination.
